alerts.title: Permanent fire prohibition on Teewah Beach
alerts.description: A QPWS imposed fire prohibition is in place in the Cooloola Recreation Area, except at Poverty Point camping area. Campfires must not be lit anywhere else in the recreation area including in the Teewah Beach camping zones 1-7.
alerts.details:
A QPWS imposed fire prohibition is in place in the Cooloola Recreation Area, except at Poverty Point camping area. Campfires must not be lit anywhere else in the recreation area including in the Teewah Beach camping zones 1-7.

This permanent fire prohibition was implemented to reduce the risk of bushfires, protect critical habitat of native wildlife, enhance visitor safety from campfire related injuries and reduce rubbish from non-combustible materials being burnt.

Fully enclosed cooking and heating appliances can still be used in camping areas that meet the below requirements.

  • The appliance must use gas or manufactured fuel (heat beads, briquettes). Manufactured fuel does not include timber or wood.
  • It must be used only for cooking and/or heating.
  • It must be a minimum of 20cm off the ground and more than 2m from flammable materials, which includes vegetation. 
  • It must not have the potential to generate airborne embers, or possibly ignite nearby ground fuels.
  • It must be fully self-contained (heat source enclosed and no exposed flame) and never left unattended when in use.
  • Appliances that are not fully self-contained, such as braziers, are not permitted.
  • All appliances, materials and burnt fuel must be removed from the recreation area on your departure.

On the spot fines of $806 can be issued to people who light fires during a fire prohibition.

Campfires are permitted at Poverty Point camping area and at nearby Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area unless in accordance with all local directions for that area.

For details on the difference between a Queensland Fire and Emergency Services (QFES) total fire ban and a QPWS fire prohibition and approved cooking appliances visit the DES Camp fires and cooking web page.

QPWS thanks you for your cooperation while we implement this management change.

alerts.title: George Point toilet removed due to erosion
alerts.description: George Point camping area on the southern coastline of Hinchinbrook Island National Park has been affected by severe erosion due to ongoing high tides over the past several years.
alerts.details:
George Point camping area on the southern coastline of Hinchinbrook Island National Park has been affected by severe erosion due to ongoing high tides over the past several years.

The camping area signage and infrastructure has been washed out and the toilet has been removed.

There is bush camping available nearby if needed by Thorsborne Trail hikers or sea kayakers. Space for camping is available under a large stand of trees approximately 250m to the northeast along the beach (prior to reaching the camping area when hiking from north to south). Please be aware there is no formal camping area and no toilet/pack rack. There is no boat-based camping available.

QPWS is currently reviewing options for the future of the site as part of the Thorsborne Trail Enhancement project.

alerts.title: Camp site booking restrictions due to tidal inundation
alerts.description: Several low-lying camp sites adjacent to Pumicestone Passage on the western side of Bribie Island Recreation Area will be closed on a recurring basis throughout 2025 due to tidal inundation from forecast large high tides.
alerts.details:
Several low-lying camp sites adjacent to Pumicestone Passage on the western side of Bribie Island Recreation Area will be closed on a recurring basis throughout 2025 due to tidal inundation from forecast large high tides.

Affected camp sites include:

  • Lime Pocket camping area - All sites
  • Mission Point camping area - Sites 1-6 
  • Gallagher Point camping area - All sites
  • Poverty Creek camping area - Sites 4 & 5

Please note heights are taken from the Brisbane Bar tide chart. This is due to the changes in water flow caused by the northern breakaway section of Bribie Island.

On waterfront sites, campers should, where possible, consider placing tents and camping equipment back from the water’s edge to avoid any inundation from passing boats.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Stay up to date with weather forecasts, conditions and warnings.

alerts.title: Changes to Scenic Rim Trail end point - Main Range National Park
alerts.description: Due to restoration works on the Cunningham Highway, changes to the Scenic Rim Trail end point at The Crest carpark are in place.
alerts.details:
Due to restoration works on the Cunningham Highway, changes to the Scenic Rim Trail end point at The Crest carpark are in place.

Access to The Crest carpark is closed to all traffic. There will be no access to the carpark for visitors to be picked up/dropped off.

The Scenic Rim Trail will now end at West Gap Creek picnic area, a further 2.5km on from The Crest carpark.

Approaching the southern end of the Scenic Rim Trail, visitors will be directed to continue past The Crest carpark to the West Gap Creek picnic area via the Box Forest track. 

This will add an additional 2.5km to the final day of the Scenic Rim Trail, for a total 15.8km walk from Banshee walkers’ camp to West Gap Creek picnic area.  

Toilet facilities at The Crest will remain open for visitors using walking tracks.

Visitors are reminded that parking and walking along the Cunningham Highway is prohibited. 

Facilities will reopen when construction is completed.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please monitor Queensland Traffic for updated information regarding road and traffic conditions.

parks.name: Scenic Rim Trail, Main Range National Park

alerts.title: Nearshore landslide Inskip Peninsula
alerts.description: Nearshore landslides and dynamic coastal activities are common within the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area.
alerts.details:
Nearshore landslides and dynamic coastal activities are common within the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area.

Recent high tides and steady shoreline retrogression has forced the requirement to remove a toilet facility within the Sarawak West camping area. As a result, camping capacity has been reduced in the area whilst the removal and relocation of the toilet facility takes place.

Campers and pedestrians should exercise caution and check access conditions as landslides can occur anywhere at any time. This is part of ongoing natural coastal erosion. 

For your safety and to avoid injuries:

  • Keep well back from sand cliffs and waters’ edge as unstable beach sand may collapse without warning.
  • Avoid swimming or wading around the landslide.
  • Be aware that submerged objects and strong underwater currents may be present.
  • Nearby trees or branches may fall at any time.
  • Supervise children at all times on the beach.
  • Observe all signage, barriers, and directions from Rangers, and do not enter closed areas.

Ensure compliance with any signage for your safety.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

For your safety please use caution whilst visiting the park.

alerts.details:
Due to significant erosion, the toilet at the Russell Island camping area has been removed. Please bring a portable camping toilet or chemical toilet when camping.

Erosion has significantly affected the northern beach of the low-lying sandy portion of Russell Island, requiring removal of the toilet and a reduction in the capacity of the camping area.

Russell Island is a Commonwealth Island managed jointly by Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Further assessments will occur to determine if there is another suitable location on Russell Island for a camping area or other appropriate recreational opportunities.

alerts.title: Thorsborne Trail 2026 permit release
alerts.description: QPWS has taken steps to improve the experience for people booking camping permits for the Thorsborne Trail, by changing to a hiking seasons model. Camping permits for the entire 2026 hiking season will be released all at once on 16 December 2025 at 10am (Queensland time).
alerts.details:
QPWS has taken steps to improve the experience for people booking camping permits for the Thorsborne Trail, by changing to a hiking seasons model. Camping permits for the entire 2026 hiking season will be released all at once on 16 December 2025 at 10am (Queensland time).

The Thorsborne Trail is now booked differently to other camping areas and great walks in Queensland, and differently to how it was booked before. Visit Thorsborne Trail bookings to familiarise yourself with the process well before the permit release, as permits for the peak hiking season (May-September) will sell out within an hour of the release. Be prepared with backup dates if you are initially unsuccessful.

Visit qld.gov.au/ThorsborneTrailHikingSeasons for information and updates about the changes including the camping permit release schedule. This page contains FAQs and information about how to be best prepared for the permit release.

To help spread hiker numbers more evenly across the trail and camping areas and avoid crowding, QPWS is also trialling a change from 40 people at any one time on the trail, to 12 people starting the trail each day. This will maintain similar usage consistent with Visitor Strategy limits.

The 2026 hiking season is 1 March-31 December. The standard annual seasonal closure period 1 January-28 February will remain in place to manage the increased risk of unsafe conditions at this time of year.

parks.name: Thorsborne Trail, Hinchinbrook Island National Park

alerts.title: Notice of extended baiting program for feral pigs and foxes on Conway National Park, Dryander National Park, Dryander State Forest and Dryander Forest Reserve
alerts.description: The Department of the Environment, Tourism, Science and Innovation is undertaking a ground baiting program from 25 March 2025 to 25 March 2026. Manufactured baits will be used to control feral pigs and foxes on Conway National Park (Lot 43 on NPW1144 and Lot 1 on NPW1145), Dryander National Park (Lot 24 on AP19346), Dryander State Forest (Lot 432 on AP19346) and Dryander Forest Reserve (Lot 5 on AP19346). Notices will be placed at the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service office at Jubilee Pocket and the Whitsunday Regional Council offices at Proserpine and Cannonvale for one week prior to each baiting event. These notices will remain in place for four weeks after baiting has finished. Notices will also be placed at the entrances of the Conway Circuit on Conway National Park and at Double Bay on Dryander National Park. A Park Alert will also be placed on the Department of Environment, Tourism, Science and Innovation website (www.detsi.qld.gov.au) for the same period. Dogs and other domestic animals are not allowed within protected areas. Steps must be taken to ensure domestic dogs do not gain access to the baits or poisoned animals. Neighbours should restrain dogs and other domestic animals during baiting programs. For more information, please contact the department on 13 QGOV (13 74 68).

alerts.title: Exposed sand cliff and dune landslide danger
alerts.description: Exposed sand cliffs and dunes along Teewah Beach, Rainbow Beach and Double Island Point are unstable and can collapse without warning.
alerts.details:
Exposed sand cliffs and dunes along Teewah Beach, Rainbow Beach and Double Island Point are unstable and can collapse without warning.

Falling boulders and landslides are common and can cause serious injury or death.

   • NEVER climb or dig into sand cliffs.

   • Avoid standing, sitting or parking near the base of the sand cliffs.

   • Supervise children at all times

For your safety please use caution whilst visiting the park.

alerts.title: Hazards impacting beach and driving conditions in Moreton Bay Coastal Parks
alerts.description: Weather events combined with abnormally high tides have caused severe beach erosion along exposed eastern beaches on Bribie Island, Mulgumpin (Moreton Island), Minjerribah (North Stradbroke Island) and South Stradbroke Island.
alerts.details:
Weather events combined with abnormally high tides have caused severe beach erosion along exposed eastern beaches on Bribie Island, Mulgumpin (Moreton Island), Minjerribah (North Stradbroke Island) and South Stradbroke Island.

Motorists should use caution when travelling along the open sections of beach and travel at a reduced speed to avoid hazards such as steep sand dunes, hidden banks, fallen trees, exposed coffee rock, WWII structures and large debris. The extreme tides have deposited large amounts of rubbish and potentially hazardous material. For your safety, please avoid any rubbish and prevent children from playing near it.

Beach travel is recommended one hour either side of low tide. Travel three hours either side of high tide should be avoided.

Driving over vegetated dunes is not permitted despite conditions. Fines apply for anyone driving or parking on vegetated dunes.

Lagoons are flowing across beaches and deep washouts are likely around them with conditions changing on a tidal basis. Check depth before crossing lagoons as fast flowing water and soft sand can make vehicle crossing dangerous.

Steep sand dunes along eroded beaches are very unstable and can collapse bringing down trees, without warning. Avoid driving or parking close to eroded dunes. People have suffered serious injuries including death from being buried under collapsing dunes.  For yours and your families safety:

  • DO NOT climb or dig into sand dunes.

  • Avoid standing, sitting or parking your vehicle at the base of dunes.

  • NEVER allow children to play on or dig into dunes.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

New waste stations are located at the portable toilet waste facility site at:

  • Freshwater Road, off Rainbow Beach Road

Beagle, M.V. Natone and S.S. Dorrigo camping areas. No bins are available at Pelican Bay camping area, but campers can use bins located at other Inskip camping areas.

alerts.title: Partial reopening UPDATE: Lawn Hill Gorge section: Boodjamulla National Park (Aboriginal Land)
alerts.description: Following significant flooding events in 2023 and 2024, the Boodjamulla Co-operative Management Council (BCMC) continues rebuilding efforts to allow for staged reopening of visitor facilities at the Lawn Hill Gorge section of Boodjamulla National Park (Aboriginal Land).
alerts.details:
Following significant flooding events in 2023 and 2024, the Boodjamulla Co-operative Management Council (BCMC) continues rebuilding efforts to allow for staged reopening of visitor facilities at the Lawn Hill Gorge section of Boodjamulla National Park (Aboriginal Land).

Staged reopening

From Friday 4 July 2025, the following visitor opportunities are available at the Lawn Hill Gorge section of Boodjamulla National Park (Aboriginal Land):

  • Constance Range walking track
  • Lawn Hill Creek – for swimming and watercraft (one way in/one way out)
  • Camp site at Lawn Hill Gorge (with toilet facilities) – available to authorised commercial tour operators initially.

From Friday 7 November 2025, open visitor facilities will include:

  • Lawn Hill Gorge camping area - available to all campers
    • 4 tent only sites
    • 14 'multi-use' sites (camper trailer, 4WD campervan, off-road caravan)
    • 1 commercial operator camp site
    • Amenities (toilets open, no showers)
    • Non-potable water (not drinking water)
  • Constance Range walking track, Duwadarri lookout walking track
  • Lawn Hill Creek - for swimming and watercraft (one way in/one way out).

NOTE: Continued monitoring of on-site conditions will occur, and a park-wide summer/wet season closure may become necessary. Road conditions and closures and heatwave warnings will be monitored closely, and this park alert updated as necessary.

For your safety

The flooding events have altered the look and feel of the gorge, but it remains a stunning and culturally significant place. While the area is regenerating, your safety is our top priority. Please note the following:

  • Construction zones: Some areas remain active construction sites and are closed to visitors. Signs, bunting and fences mark these zones. Please follow all signage and directions from Rangers or on-site personnel.
  • Daily temperatures are now reaching beyond the high 30 degree celcius, heatwave warnings have been issued and there is limited shade: Shade is currently limited on land and in the water. Plan your visit carefully – bring at least 2 litres of drinking water per person per day, and wear a hat, long-sleeved shirt and covered shoes. Carry a first-aid kit and aim to explore during the cooler parts of the day.
  • Watercraft and swimming areas: Entry to Lawn Hill Creek is one way in and one way out. You must exit from the same location you entered.
  • Swimming distances and fitness: There are no shaded areas or stopping points between the entry point to Lawn Hill Creek and Indarri Falls. Visitors should carefully assess their swimming ability and stamina before entering the water.
  • Remote location: Lawn Hill Gorge is remote, and Rangers may not always be available. Visitors must be self-sufficient, responsible for your own safety, and prepared for emergencies.
  • Emergency contacts: For emergencies, call Triple Zero (000). Consider carrying a satellite phone or personal locator beacon (PLB).

The Boodjamulla Cooperative Management Council (i.e. the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and Waanyi People) thank the local community and stakeholders for their patience and support while work continues to safely restore and rebuild flood-damaged facilities and infrastructure.

The southern sections of Boodjamulla National Park (Aboriginal Land)—Riversleigh D Site (part of the Australian Fossil Mammal Sites World Heritage Area) and Miyumba camping area—remain fully open for visitors.

alerts.title: Challenging seasonal hiking conditions
alerts.description: Hiking the Thorsborne Trail is considerably challenging during the summer months between October to March.
alerts.details:
Hiking the Thorsborne Trail is considerably challenging during the summer months between October to March.

Conditions are extremely hot and humid at this time of year, increasing the risk of heat-related injuries. Hikers can suffer heat exhaustion.

Freshwater sources often dry up in October-December. The wet season usually begins in December. When the wet season starts, high rainfall can cause creeks to rise rapidly and crossings to become dangerous. Extreme weather events are also more likely during the wet season.

QPWS strongly recommends careful consideration of choosing to undertake the Thorsborne Trail hike during the summer months.     

The Thorsborne Trail is closed seasonally from the start of January to the end of February due to the high risk of unsafe conditions over this period.

alerts.title: Marine Turtle Season 2025-2026
alerts.description: Mon Repos is renowned for being home to the largest population of nesting marine turtles on the eastern Australian mainland. Tickets for the 2025/26 Mon Repos Turtle Encounter tours are on sale from Tuesday 2 September 2025.
alerts.details:
Mon Repos is renowned for being home to the largest population of nesting marine turtles on the eastern Australian mainland. Tickets for the 2025/26 Mon Repos Turtle Encounter tours are on sale from Tuesday 2 September 2025.

  • Mon Repos Turtle Encounter offers a rare chance to experience endangered marine turtles up close with Park Rangers or a Turtle Guide volunteer.

  • For the first time, tickets sales for the Mon Repos Turtle Encounter will be hosted on the National Parks Booking Service, this online service will allow visitors to conveniently book visitor attraction tours available at Mon Repos Turtle Centre.

  • Turtle Encounter Tour tickets are on sale from 1pm on Tuesday 2 September 2025. As tickets are highly sought after, it is recommended to book in advance to secure your opportunity to witness this incredible spectacle. Familiarise yourself with the online booking site.

  • Magnificent nesting turtles start the season off coming ashore to lay eggs (November- early February) and then later in the season hatchlings emerge to make thier way to the ocean (late January- end March)

  • To protect nesting and hatching turtles, only Turtle Encounter tour participants are allowed in Mon Repos Conservation Park and on Mon Repos beach after 6pm.

  • Read about Turtle Encounter tours before you book

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.title: Dingo (Wongari) Seasonal Information - Rearing Season
alerts.description: Give dingoes space, Kgari is their place. Limiting dingo-human interactions, particularly during wongari (dingo) rearing and emergence season, is critical to the welfare of pups.
alerts.details:
Give dingoes space, Kgari is their place. Limiting dingo-human interactions, particularly during wongari (dingo) rearing and emergence season, is critical to the welfare of pups.

This is a particularly important time for pups to learn natural hunting and survival skills and to avoid habituation towards people. Take particular care and slow down when driving on K’gari as pups are emerging from their dens and exploring their environment, and this is the time when they are most at risk of vehicle strike.

Dingo rearing and emergence season means:

  • Dingo pups will venture out of their dens and explore their surroundings
  • Adult dingoes will be teaching their young natural hunting and survival skills
  • Dingoes may be determined and aggressive in their search for food and females will aggressively defend their young
  • Female dingoes that are feeding young can lose condition and become naturally lean during this time
  • Every time a dingo receives food from people its chance of survival is reduced – let young wongari grow up wild, do not feed them or leave food available

Visitors, tour operators and residents are advised to be dingo-safe! on K’gari. It is recommended that families with young children camp in fenced QPWS camping areas at Lake Boomanjin, Central Station, Dundubara, Waddy Point and eastern beach fenced areas (Wongai, One Tree Rocks, Cornwells, Eli), or at fenced private camping areas at Dilli Village or Cathedral Beach.

Be dingo-safe! Visit https://parks.detsi.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes/dingo-safe

  • NEVER feed dingoes.
  • Always stay within arm’s reach of children, even small teenagers.
  • Walk in groups and carry a long dingo safety stick.
  • Do not run. Running or jogging can trigger a negative dingo interaction.
  • Camp in fenced areas when possible.
  • Secure all rubbish, fish, bait and tackle.
  • Never store food or food containers in tents.
  • No food to lakeshores.


Report dingo encounters – email dingo.ranger@detsi.qld.gov.au, tell the nearest QPWS ranger, or phone (07) 4127 9150 – mobile phone charges may apply. Take note of location, vehicle registration, dingo ear tag colour, number and which ear.

For further information about wongari (dingoes) on K’gari (Fraser Island) please visit https://parks.detsi.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes

Your safety is our concern, but your responsibility.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

alerts.title: Aerial Baiting Program
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service and Partnerships (QPWS&P) is undertaking an aerial baiting program on 23 October 2025. Sodium Fluoroacetate (1080) meat baits will be used to control feral pigs on Conway National Park (Lot 43 on NPW1144 and Lot 1 on NPW1145), Dryander National Park (Lot 24 on AP19346), Dryander State Forest (Lot 432 on AP19346) and Dryander Forest Reserve (Lot 5 on AP19346). A licensed operator will distribute the baits by helicopter. These baits will not be collected. Notices will be placed at the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service office at Jubilee Pocket and the Whitsunday Regional Council offices at Proserpine and Cannonvale for one week prior to the baiting event. These notices will remain in place for four weeks after baiting has finished. Notices will also be placed at the entrances of the Conway Circuit on Conway National Park and at Double Bay on Dryander National Park. A Park Alert will also be placed on the Department of Environment and Science website (www.detsi.qld.gov.au) for the same period. Dogs and other domestic animals are not permitted within the protected areas. Steps must be taken to ensure domestic dogs do not gain access to the 1080 baits or poisoned animals. Neighbours should restrain dogs and other domestic animals during baiting programs.

alerts.title: Drive with care during marine turtle nesting season
alerts.description: From November to May, you may see turtles crossing the beach to lay their eggs or hatchlings making their way from nest to ocean for the first time. Motorists and visitors to Bribie Island National Park and Recreation Area are asked to minimise disturbance and human impacts to nesting marine turtles.
alerts.details:
From November to May, you may see turtles crossing the beach to lay their eggs or hatchlings making their way from nest to ocean for the first time. Motorists and visitors to Bribie Island National Park and Recreation Area are asked to minimise disturbance and human impacts to nesting marine turtles.

When driving on the beach:

  • Plan to travel at 2 hours either side of low tide. Keep to the hard sand well below the high tide line to avoid making wheel ruts that create barriers to hatchling movement down the beach.
  • Avoid driving on the beach at night. This is when turtles will lay their eggs, and hatchlings are most likely to be emerging. Exercise caution and look out for turtles and turtle hatchlings when traversing on the beach.
  • If turtles are making their way across the beach - slow down, stop and wait for the turtles to reach the ocean or the dunes. On-the-spot fines apply to visitors disturbing turtle hatchlings or turtle nests.
  • Driving over vegetated dunes is dangerous and prohibited. It is damaging to the environment and can impact turtle nests, on-the-spot fines apply.

‘Cut the glow to help turtles go’. Artificial lights can affect a turtle’s ability to see the natural horizon over the ocean. Hatchlings can become disoriented, veer from their natural path and head towards the artificial light. When camping during the nesting season you can help cut the glow of lights affecting beaches by switching off unnecessary lights on the beach after 7.30pm.

Observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers.

To report marine animal strandings (of sick, injured or dead turtles, dolphin, dugongs or whales) call the 1300 130 372.

For your safety please avoid interaction with the wildlife.

parks.name: Bribie Island National Park and Recreation Area

alerts.title: Fire prohibition in place
alerts.description: A fire prohibition is active from 12/09/2025 until further notice due to dry conditions and the increased risk of bushfire.
alerts.details:
A fire prohibition is active from 12/09/2025 until further notice due to dry conditions and the increased risk of bushfire.

Fires must not be lit anywhere in:

  • Porcupine Gorge National Park
  • White Mountains National Park
  • Blackbraes National Park

During the fire prohibition, only fully enclosed cooking and heating appliances that meet the below requirements are permitted.

The appliance:

· Must use gas or manufactured fuel (eg. briquettes). Manufactured fuel does not include milled timber or sawn/cut tree parts.

· Must be used only for cooking and/or heating.

· Must be a minimum of 20cm off the ground and more than 2m from flammable materials, which includes vegetation.

· Must not have the potential to generate airborne embers or possibly ignite nearby ground fuels.

· Must be fully self-contained (heat source enclosed and no exposed flame) and never left unattended when in use.

Appliances that are not fully self-contained, such as braziers, are not permitted.

All appliances, materials and burnt fuel must be removed from the area on your departure.

Visitors must comply with this fire prohibition, on-site signs and any directions given by Rangers. Penalties apply.

QPWS will continue to monitor the situation and update this Park Alert should conditions change.

To report any bushfires, call Triple Zero (000)

For your safety please obey all fire restrictions.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: Inskip Peninsula camping area boundary realignment following ex-Tropical Cyclone Alfred storm damage
alerts.description: During ex-Tropical Cyclone Alfred, storm surges and swell eroded the eastern-facing beaches of Inskip Peninsula, and caused loss of sand, destabilisation of the dunes and loss of existing campground border fencing.
alerts.details:
During ex-Tropical Cyclone Alfred, storm surges and swell eroded the eastern-facing beaches of Inskip Peninsula, and caused loss of sand, destabilisation of the dunes and loss of existing campground border fencing.

A team of geotechnical erosion experts was engaged to investigate the impacts of cyclone events at the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area and to provide technical advice regarding site safety. Based on the findings and recommendations from the geotechnical assessment, the camping area boundaries will be realigned to establish a 20-metre retrogression buffer zone landward of the current treeline.

This boundary realignment is necessary due to ongoing coastal erosion, nearshore landslide risk, and damage sustained to existing infrastructure. The revised layout will enhance visitor safety by reducing exposure to unstable shoreline areas and future erosion hazards. 

Installation of the new fencing will take place between 10 November and 05 December 2025 (weather and logistics permitting) as the three impacted campgrounds will be closed during this time for pre-scheduled maintenance closures. The following camping areas will be closed for construction during this period:

  • CLOSED: M.V. Beagle (10-16 November 2025 inclusive)
  • CLOSED: M.V. Sarawak (17 – 27 November 2025 inclusive) 
  • PARTIALLY CLOSED: Sarawak West (05 November – 05 December 2025 inclusive). A small section of camping area is barriered off for construction purposes.

Observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers, and do not enter closed areas.

All permits for the closed areas are suspended for the duration of the closure (not including Sarawak West). Alternate camping areas are available at Inskip Peninsula camping area for the duration of the closures.

Apply for a camping permit refund online at www.qld.gov.au/camping. Log into your account and cancel your booking to receive an automatic refund or request to change your booking to another camping area at Inskip. 

QPWS thanks you for your support and cooperation.

alerts.title: Upcoming wet season closure: Rinyirru (Lakefield) National Park (CYPAL)
alerts.description: Rinyirru (Lakefield) National Park (CYPAL) will close for the wet season on Monday 1 December 2025. Predicting re-opening dates is a challenge and will depend on type of wet season, road and weather conditions, as well as ensuring camp sites are safe to re-open.
alerts.details:
Rinyirru (Lakefield) National Park (CYPAL) will close for the wet season on Monday 1 December 2025. Predicting re-opening dates is a challenge and will depend on type of wet season, road and weather conditions, as well as ensuring camp sites are safe to re-open.

The following camping areas south of Lakefield ranger base are anticipated to reopen Monday 1 June 2026:

  • Dingo Waterhole
  • Horseshoe Lagoon
  • Kalpowar Crossing
  • Kennedy Bend
  • Mick Fienn Waterhole
  • Old Faithful Waterhole
  • Old Laura Homestead
  • Six Mile Waterhole
  • Twelve Mile Lagoon
  • Welcome Waterhole

Due to the unpredictable nature of wet seasons and the need to open camp sites when it is safe to do so, the following sites (north of Lakefield ranger base) will be available to be booked from Wednesday 15 July 2026. Conditions throughout the wet season will be closely monitored and this date will be modified accordingly. This park alert will be updated as it becomes clearer when these sites can be safely opened:

  • Annie River
  • Basin Hole
  • Bizant River
  • Bottom Whiphandle Waterhole
  • Brown Creek
  • Five Mile Creek
  • Hann Crossing
  • Hanushs Waterhole
  • Melaleuca Waterhole
  • Midway Waterhole
  • Orange Plain Waterhole
  • Saltwater Crossing
  • Seven Mile
  • Sweetwater Lake
  • Top Whiphandle Waterhole

Please monitor park alerts for current information.

alerts.title: Temporary Closure Firebreak Maintenance Works - Daisy Hill Conservation Park - Venman Bushland National Park
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be commencing maintenance works within in Daisy Hill Conservation Park and Venman Bushland National Park between the dates of 17/11/25 - 31/12/25 .
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) will be commencing maintenance works within in Daisy Hill Conservation Park and Venman Bushland National Park between the dates of 17/11/25 - 31/12/25 .

Heavy machinery will be utilised during these works.

Please follow directions of signage and advice from Rangers and machine operators during this time.

This maintenance work will be repairing damage to firelines and upgrading firelines to be compliance for fire management and operations the following firebreaks will be restricted:

- Barking Dog Break

- Shailer Break

- Venman Road

- Red Road

Works are part of a strategic plan to ensure public safety, property protection and the management of fire within the Conservation Park.

All other firebreaks within Daisy Hill Conservation Park and Venman Bushland National Park remain unaffected.

QPWS apologises for any inconvenience during the completion of these works.

Facilities will reopen when construction is completed.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

Due to the changed conditions the visitor experience may be affected.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

For your safety please use caution whilst visiting the park.

For your safety please slow down and observe all directions and signs.

For your safety please proceed with caution along all park access roads.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

The park will reopen when conditions are considered safe.
